column1: The settlement was originally a stage coach station called Griders. According to the Roseville Historical Society
column2: in 1864 the Central Pacific Railroad tracks were constructed northeastward from Sacramento. The point where the tracks met the California Central Railroad line was named "Junction". Junction eventually became known as Roseville (cf. Louis Rose). In 1909
column3: three years after the Southern Pacific Railroad moved its facilities from Rocklin to Roseville
column4: the town became an incorporated city. What followed was a period of expansion
column5: with the community building more than 100 structures

column1: The city was a railroad town for decades
column2: with the railroad employing up to 1
column3: 225 people by 1929
column4: out of a population of only 6
column5: 425 people. With the onset of World War II
column6: the rail yards became busier than ever and the post-war building boom brought continued prosperity. However
column7: the nature of the city changed dramatically in the 1950s.

column1: During the 1950s the railroad continued to expand and upgrade
column2: converting its steam engine fleet to all diesel engines by the end of the decade. However
column3: the railroads began falling in the shadow of air travel and the development of the national Interstate Highway System. Thus
column4: although the railroad remained (and still remains) a major employer
column5: the expansion of the city began branching out into other employment sectors. Another important change during this period was the Washington Boulevard (then called Seawell) railroad underpass construction in 1950. While this improved the ability of people to travel from one side of the tracks to the other
column6: it meant that people were no longer traveling through the Roseville business district north of the tracks. The completion of Interstate 80 in 1956 shifted the population from downtown to what would become known as East Roseville. The old downtown area slid into a gradual decline.

column1: Roseville has a hot-summer Mediterranean climate that is characterized by cool
column3: usually snowless winters and hot
column4: dry summers (Köppen Csa). The wet season is generally October through April. Because Roseville is east of Sacramento and at a higher elevation
column5: it receives slightly more rainfall. Average daily high temperatures range from 53 °F (12 °C) in January to 94 °F (34 °C) in July and 92 °F in August (33 °C). Daily low temperatures range from 39 °F in winter to 61 °F in summer (4 to 16 °C).
